author: joshuaisbuilding
content:
Watching back EIPIP 33 and I had a thought about allowing links in EIPs that wasn‚Äôt brought up on the call.

The general thought process in Academia is that linking to dynamic content (websites) creates a fragile artefact - i.e. the writing doesn‚Äôt stand the test of time due to broken links or content that may change over time.

Might not be at all relevant but I thought I‚Äôd throw it out there.

author: poojaranjan
content: This is a good point and a possible reasons why editors would want to keep external links outside of the EIPs. Though, adding external link is not prohibited, in general, avoiding unless needed, could be a good practice.

author: lightclient
content: This is the general argument for only allowing links of high quality (e.g. things that will continue to be there 10, 20, plus years on). The issue is that there aren't enough people interested editing EIPs to ensure they are high quality and not enough people are used to writing in this way (more formal/academic style), so it's hard to achieve the ideal

author: joshuaisbuilding
content:
The idea being that the requirement of high quality and ‚Äòtimeless‚Äô links would by default remove any self-interested shilling? Is that the main issue not allowing links protected against?

On helping editing - I‚Äôm trying to digest the information surrounding it, I think it is something I would be interested in but not really sure how long it would take to make myself useful in any meaningful way.

author: lightclient
content: I think self-interested shilling is a separate issue and is less prevalent than honest authors naively using a new article / twitter link

author: joshuaisbuilding
content: Maybe I‚Äôm being naive but it doesn‚Äôt sound like a hard problem to solve. Surely anyone creating an EIP is motivated to see their creation progress through the pipeline.

author: lightclient
content: You'd be surprised then at how many EIPs die off after a few change requests or after it's merged as a draft üôÇ

author: joshuaisbuilding
content:
I see. Though I don‚Äôt see a free for all on links resolving that..

I‚Äôm a newbie to it so as I said probably being a bit naive, thanks for entertaining my questions üòÉ

author: lightclient
content: a free for all on links is just one thing, it would be great if EIPs were held to a higher standard in all aspects - but there isn't enough energy on either side for that

author: lightclient
content: we're talking about links because the policy is much clearer than enforcing guidelines on the quality of the writing

author: joshuaisbuilding
content: Not an easy problem to solve

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
"49% of supreme court links are broken": https://youtu.be/LKbOPYnUlXs?t=1015

My preference would be for 100% of links to work on a smaller pool of linked content than even for 2/3rds of links to work on a much larger pool of linked content. There are so many broken links on posts / registries listing hackathon entrants that the value of these sites themselves are depreciate and the UX is horrendous even two years later. 

Is there a way for EF to request Wayback machine links? We could continue high yet subjective standards to reduce the amount of sites that'll be backed-up (e.g. the principle of preferring fewer links).

author: sky.cactus
content: I often tell people to include links to PDFs as assets, which is akin to using way back machine's but without the reliance of wayback machine.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
An immediate change could be to adopt reference lists at the end of articles before the citation and copyright sections. 
Properly formatting references in academia is a pain I don't think anyone wants to replicate, but to use *[n]* after a hyperlink is displayed and just having the plaintext of a url could be a bit safer. Sometimes you can search keywords or if you're familiar with the site even find the original content through other means. 

e.g. "...EIP-8 discusses this further [3]...
[3]: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-8 "

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think that addresses the problem, it just moves the problem to a different place in the document.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Sidenote: it would be lovely if we could have bibtex / biblatex source in the citation section (or a link to it üòõ )

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Agreed it doesn't solve the problem, just a slightly nicer UX. I forgot you still have the url even for a hyperlink üò¶
